Itis only by remembering this weakness that we can realize the intensity of patriotism which kept him unswervingly true to his ideal of a free republic and gave him contage for his last grand struggle in its behalf. In his blind idolatry of this ideal he showed little politica] sagacity. The irresistible logie of the events of the last hundred years made no appeal to his understanding. He could comprehend neither the resistless forces at work for the destruction of the Roman republic nor the hope of renewed national life under imperial rule.
